clusters.title: ‘All you need is a chair and a view’: could daily ‘dusking’ make us healthier and happier?
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘All you need is a chair and a view’: could daily ‘dusking’ make us healthier and happier?

items.title: ‘All you need is a chair and a view’: could daily ‘dusking’ make us healthier and happier?
items.standfirst: An old Dutch ritual of going outside to watch the coming of night – or dusking – is having a revival across Europe. Fans of the practice say it’s a great way to disconnect from screens and find peace I’m wandering around a walled garden on the edge of the North York Moors at dusk. The darkening sky is faintly illuminated by a sharp sliver of crescent moon and the first stars. Bats are swooping in search of supper, an owl is softly hooting and the dark outline of a ruined castle looms beyond the walls.But what is really striking about the scene is what’s missing: artificial light. There are no solar lamps or electric bulbs; no torches or phone screens. As parts of the garden recede into the gloom, others are thrown into sharp relief: the bare branches of winter trees; a russet-coloured hedge; clumps of snowdrops, glowing bright in the moonlight. Continue reading...
items.content: An old Dutch ritual of going outside to watch the coming of night – or dusking – is having a revival across Europe. Fans of the practice say it’s a great way to disconnect from screens and find peace I’m wandering around a walled garden on the edge of the North York Moors at dusk. The darkening sky is faintly illuminated by a sharp sliver of crescent moon and the first stars. Bats are swooping in search of supper, an owl is softly hooting and the dark outline of a ruined castle looms beyond the walls.But what is really striking about the scene is what’s missing: artificial light. There are no solar lamps or electric bulbs; no torches or phone screens. As parts of the garden recede into the gloom, others are thrown into sharp relief: the bare branches of winter trees; a russet-coloured hedge; clumps of snowdrops, glowing bright in the moonlight. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Dusking practice involves watching sunset
Benefits for mental and physical health
Disconnect from screens and technology
Peaceful and calming experience
Increased sense of well-being and happiness

clusters.title: Jeremy Webb died of a meat allergy triggered by a tick bite. How do you avoid ticks and safely remove them?
clusters.neutral_headline: Jeremy Webb died of a meat allergy triggered by a tick bite. How do you avoid ticks and safely remove them?

items.title: Jeremy Webb died of a meat allergy triggered by a tick bite. How do you avoid ticks and safely remove them?
items.standfirst: After a coroner concluded 16-year-old Australian died of a bite-induced meat allergy, we look at how to spot symptoms and preventative measuresFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastMyfanwy Webb remembers her son Jeremy was “always getting ticks” because he spent a lot of time in the bush, camping and mountain bike riding, around the property where he grew up on the Central Coast of New South Wales.When Jeremy began to get really bad reactions to eating meat, or even when the scent wafted through the house if she was cooking a pork roast, Webb remembered reading an article about an immunologist who identified the connection between tick bites and developing mammalian meat allergy. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: The first lady is a Trump and therefore automatically qualified to do anything her heart desires“We ended DEI in America,” Donald Trump boasted during his State of the Union (SOTU) address on Tuesday.Unlike many things the president said in his excruciatingly long SOTU speech, this was actually half true. clusters.title: ‘Viruses don’t know borders’: US anti-vaccine rhetoric could impact global measles crisis
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘Viruses don’t know borders’: US anti-vaccine rhetoric could impact global measles crisis

items.title: ‘Viruses don’t know borders’: US anti-vaccine rhetoric could impact global measles crisis
items.standfirst: Experts say global measles vaccination rates are falling as Trump officials signal a deprioritization of the virusThe US government has amplified anti-vaccine rhetoric and signaled that it does not consider measles to be a priority, which could have global ramifications as countries around the world have lost or are on the brink of losing measles elimination status.The World Health Organization announced in late January that six European countries: the United Kingdom, Spain, Austria, Armenia, Azerbaijan and Uzbekistan had all officially lost their measles elimination status, which means the virus has been circulating continuously in those countries for more than 12 months. In order to contain measles, at least 95% of children should be fully vaccinated against it, according to health recommendations, but vaccination rates have been falling across Europe. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts say global measles vaccination rates are falling as Trump officials signal a deprioritization of the virusThe US government has amplified anti-vaccine rhetoric and signaled that it does not consider measles to be a priority, which could have global ramifications as countries around the world have lost or are on the brink of losing measles elimination status.The World Health Organization announced in late January that six European countries: the United Kingdom, Spain, Austria, Armenia, Azerbaijan and Uzbekistan had all officially lost their measles elimination status, which means the virus has been circulating continuously in those countries for more than 12 months. In order to contain measles, at least 95% of children should be fully vaccinated against it, according to health recommendations, but vaccination rates have been falling across Europe. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Anti-vaccine rhetoric affects measles crisis
Global vaccination rates are falling
US government's stance on measles vaccine
Potential consequences for global health

clusters.title: ‘I clicked on a button – and everything changed’: how a DNA test turned my life upside-down
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘I clicked on a button – and everything changed’: how a DNA test turned my life upside-down

items.title: ‘I clicked on a button – and everything changed’: how a DNA test turned my life upside-down
items.standfirst: When I found out my father had been adopted, I was curious to know more about his side of the family. Nothing could have prepared me for what I would discover …Above my grandma’s bed hung a framed black‑and-white photograph of my dad. As a small child I quietly admired it; his luminous eyes, dark hair and gentle smile. He embodied a tender yet spirited early adulthood, staring into the future. Handsome and seeking.As I grew older, I would discover that it was not, in fact, a photograph of my dad but of a man called Elvis Presley. Apparently he was very famous. My grandma had been a lifelong fan. My parents laughed – an adorable mistake – but I felt a hot pulse of humiliation. Continue reading...
items.content: When I found out my father had been adopted, I was curious to know more about his side of the family. Nothing could have prepared me for what I would discover …Above my grandma’s bed hung a framed black‑and-white photograph of my dad. As a small child I quietly admired it; his luminous eyes, dark hair and gentle smile. He embodied a tender yet spirited early adulthood, staring into the future. Handsome and seeking.As I grew older, I would discover that it was not, in fact, a photograph of my dad but of a man called Elvis Presley. Apparently he was very famous. My grandma had been a lifelong fan. My parents laughed – an adorable mistake – but I felt a hot pulse of humiliation. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Poorly regulated clinics in England are putting children with ADHD at risk, warn doctors
clusters.neutral_headline: Poorly Regulated Clinics Put Children with ADHD at Risk

items.title: Poorly regulated clinics in England are putting children with ADHD at risk, warn doctors
items.standfirst: Private providers accused of prescribing powerful stimulants without examining young patients properlyChildren with ADHD are being put at risk by poorly regulated private clinics that prescribe powerful stimulants without key physical examinations, doctors have warned.A surge in remote-only assessments has led to what one clinician described as “widespread and unsafe practice”, where children are being diagnosed and medicated via video link. The clinical warnings have now forced health authorities in Greater Manchester to overhaul prescribing rules, mandating face-to-face checks to protect the safety of children. Continue reading...
items.content: Private providers accused of prescribing powerful stimulants without examining young patients properlyChildren with ADHD are being put at risk by poorly regulated private clinics that prescribe powerful stimulants without key physical examinations, doctors have warned.A surge in remote-only assessments has led to what one clinician described as “widespread and unsafe practice”, where children are being diagnosed and medicated via video link. The clinical warnings have now forced health authorities in Greater Manchester to overhaul prescribing rules, mandating face-to-face checks to protect the safety of children. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Private clinics prescribe stimulants without exams
Risk of misdiagnosis and overmedication
Doctors warn of unsafe practices

clusters.title: Target says it will stop selling breakfast cereals with synthetic colors
clusters.neutral_headline: Target Stops Selling Breakfast Cereals With Synthetic Colors

items.title: Target says it will stop selling breakfast cereals with synthetic colors
items.standfirst: US retailer’s decision comes as RFK Jr and Maha movement increase pressure on food industry to drop dyes like red 40The big-box US retailer Target announced on Friday that by 31 May it will only sell breakfast cereals made without certified synthetic food colors.The company is introducing the restriction amid increased pressure on the food industry from the Trump administration and the “Make America healthy again” (Maha) movement to stop using such ingredients, which they see as dangerous. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Mental health units discharging eating disorder patients with ‘dangerously low’ BMIs
clusters.neutral_headline: Mental Health Units Discharge Patients With Low BMIs

items.title: Mental health units discharging eating disorder patients with ‘dangerously low’ BMIs
items.standfirst: FoI request reveals some people sent home despite BMIs below 15 – considered to be ‘severe malnutrition’ Patients with eating disorders are being discharged from mental health units even though they are still very thin and have “dangerously low” body mass index levels.Some hospitals are sending home people whose BMIs are as low as 12.5, despite usual clinical practice in the NHS seeking to wait until a BMI of 18 or 19 has been achieved. Continue reading...
items.content: FoI request reveals some people sent home despite BMIs below 15 – considered to be ‘severe malnutrition’ Patients with eating disorders are being discharged from mental health units even though they are still very thin and have “dangerously low” body mass index levels.Some hospitals are sending home people whose BMIs are as low as 12.5, despite usual clinical practice in the NHS seeking to wait until a BMI of 18 or 19 has been achieved. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Diagnosing mental health conditions need not be a case of yes/no | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Diagnosing Mental Health Conditions Need Not Be A Case Of Yes/No

items.title: Diagnosing mental health conditions need not be a case of yes/no | Letters
items.standfirst: Responding to an article on the rising numbers of young people with mental illness or ADHD diagnoses, Sue Simmons says we all lie on a continuum, and Michael Baber calls for a more holistic approachLucy Foulkes explores the possibility that the rising numbers of young people receiving a diagnosis of mental illness or ADHD are subjects of overdiagnosis (Are we really overdiagnosing mental illness?, 22 February). She posits that changes in terminology, increasing societal awareness and reductions in stigma are all factors in the increase in diagnoses.However, there is another way of looking at this issue. If we treat ADHD as binary (you have it or you do not), we are missing the possibility that we all lie somewhere on a continuum with diagnosed ADHD towards one end (and perhaps an ability to focus and concentrate at the other). A diagnosis of ADHD then depends on where the line is drawn. I suggest that this line has been moved in recent years, so that a large group of people have been caught up in the positive ADHD group, who would not have been previously. Continue reading...
items.content: Responding to an article on the rising numbers of young people with mental illness or ADHD diagnoses, Sue Simmons says we all lie on a continuum, and Michael Baber calls for a more holistic approachLucy Foulkes explores the possibility that the rising numbers of young people receiving a diagnosis of mental illness or ADHD are subjects of overdiagnosis (Are we really overdiagnosing mental illness?, 22 February). She posits that changes in terminology, increasing societal awareness and reductions in stigma are all factors in the increase in diagnoses.However, there is another way of looking at this issue. If we treat ADHD as binary (you have it or you do not), we are missing the possibility that we all lie somewhere on a continuum with diagnosed ADHD towards one end (and perhaps an ability to focus and concentrate at the other). A diagnosis of ADHD then depends on where the line is drawn. I suggest that this line has been moved in recent years, so that a large group of people have been caught up in the positive ADHD group, who would not have been previously. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Mental health conditions exist on a continuum
Diagnosis depends on where the line is drawn
Changes in terminology affect diagnosis rates
Societal awareness and stigma reduction factor in
Holistic approach to diagnosis is being suggested
